Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Nonbinding Commitment Modeling and Control for Deployment of Distributed Flexible Energy Resources

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The recent advancements in emerging technologies and the greater integration of renewable energy resources have increased interest in distributed flexible energy resources. However, barriers to the deployment of these resources continue, due to difficulties in evaluating their contributions to the operability of the power grid, in designing compensation mechanisms, and in eliciting participation. This project will investigate market models with several novel features for encouraging the large-scale deployment of distributed flexible energy resources. In particular, neither the power aggregator nor the distributed energy resources will be required to commit in advance to buy or supply power at specific times. Instead, permissions to operate will be sent at random times to a subset of program participants, who then have the right but not the obligation to act. The research is expected to provide insights to utilities, regulators, and policy makers regarding the design of efficient and attractive deployment programs. Beyond the focus area of Clean Energy, the expected outcomes of this research will be applicable to many situations where events arrive at random times at a rate influenced by upper-level decisions.

This research aims to analyze the proposed market models in a general setting and to develop theory and algorithmic strategies for the class of two-level continuous-time stochastic control problems coupled with point processes. Statistical properties of point processes will make coordination schemes extensible to more aggregation levels and participants. By introducing randomness in opportunities to act in order to elicit behaviors, while remaining nonbinding for the participating resources, a favorable environment will be created to foster investment and the deployment of flexible resources at the level of the distribution network.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Promoting the economically-efficient deployment of distributed energy resources requires market frameworks that can accommodate a large number of resources while maintaining the operability of the power grid. This project introduces a nonbinding commitment energy market framework which offers a mutually beneficial agreement with attractive flexibility and financial benefits for utility companies and distributed energy resources.

In this project, we first establish optimal operating rules for distributed flexible energy resources participating in this market and assess the value of such a program for them. Storage operations aim to maximize the expected cumulated revenue given the innovative features of the program. Notably, the times where energy transactions are possible on the grid are modeled as a point process, which represents mathematically the random times of arrival of permissions to operate. The rate of arrival is either contractual or to be learnt. The optimal policy of the distributed agents is a building block for distributed control in this market.

This study is extended to the case where the agents have simultaneous access to the energy market and the regulation service market. Numerical methods are developed to be able to determine optimal control strategies in this setup. The sensitivity to market parameters and the compensation structure are investigated to better predict the behavior of potential participants to the program parameters.

Next, a coordination mechanism for the utility company is used to aggregate these distributed flexible energy resources over a network with the objective of maximizing grid reliability in the presence of uncertainties. The method can scale to a large number of distributed resources, taking into account network constraints at any time. The performance of this aggregation mechanism as well as a set of benchmark mechanisms are investigated using simulation studies and their impacts on the agent’s payoff and the grid.

The research results have been reported in preliminary research reports, published in peer-reviewed articles, and disseminated at conferences to the industry and to the public. Graduate students received training and participated in the research.
